thread.title_full: Will a meteor wipe out life on Earth? Scientists are examining one that already did - Mirror Online

author: Jeff Parsons
title: Will a meteor wipe out life on Earth? Scientists are examining one that already did
text:
Fears may be growing that a meteor could strike the Earth next week - but some plucky scientists are going to take a closer look at one that already hit us .
The Chicxulub crater in Mexico is widely believed to be a result of a colossal meteor striking the Earth some 65 million years ago.
The cataclysmic event trigged the extinction of the dinosaurs and left behind a crater that stretches 10 miles wide.
For the first time, scientists are preparing to examine the "peak ring" at the centre of the crater for more geological evidence.
"We expect the zone to be very sterile, but will be drilling rocks above the peak ring to see how long it took life to recover," said Professor Joanna Morgan, a geophysicist of the department of Earth Science and Engineering at Imperial College London.
A meteor crater in Arizona, USA
The team will be looking for fossils of creatures that might have been created after the impact.
They also believe it could give clues about the geology of other planets.
"We will be looking at the microbiology to see if can tell us what formed here but also what could potentially form on Mars," said Ms Morgan who is co-leading the project.
What's more, the project could help assess the potential consequences of any future asteroid impacts.
That will come as little comfort to the legions of conspiracy theorists that believe the end of days will come later this month .
Getty This would be bad news for us
But NASA indicates that if there was any object large enough to create that level of destruction, we would have seen it by now.
NASA’s Near Earth Object office at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory is at the forefront of what is now a worldwide collaboration to watch the skies for any asteroids that could do harm to our planet.
Their “Spaceguard” programme detects and tracks these objects as well as trying to determine their nature; such as what is their mass or what could they be made of.
Paul Chodas, from the Jet Propulsion Lab, said: "There is no existing evidence that an asteroid or any other celestial object is on a trajectory that will impact Earth.
"In fact, not a single one of the known objects has any credible chance of hitting our planet over the next century.
"There is no scientific basis, not one shred of evidence, that an asteroid or any other celestial object will impact Earth on those dates."
